thread.title: 25 things to do in Lou this weekend
thread.title_full: 25 things to do in Lou this weekend

title: 25 things to do in Lou this weekend
text:
25 things to do in Lou this weekend The Courier-Journal 4:23 p.m. EDT October 21, 2015 Important schedule. Wondering what's going on in Louisville? We've got you covered. We've picked 25 things you can't miss in the Derby City this week. Festivals 
Life in Color — Big Bang. Broadbent Arena, Kentucky Exposition Center, 937 Phillips Ln., 8 p.m. Friday. World’s largest paint party combining musical performances and paint cannons. For ages 16 or older. General admission: $34.70-$59; express entry: $53.70-$74.90; LIC Survivor ticket, $86.50 includes a Hard in the Paint Survival Bag, LIC bag, t-shirt, bottle of paint voucher, towel, shades and express entry. Parking $8, $20 bus. (502) 367-5000. 
Monster Mash Costume Ball. Passalino’s, 207 W. Market St., 7-11 p.m. Friday. Costume contest with prizes, appetizers from Martini’s Italian Bistro, cash bar, raffles and drawings. Proceeds benefits The Arrow Fund. $25 advance, $30 at the door. www.thearrowfund.org . 
The Future is Unwritten. Revelry Boutique Gallery, 742 E. Market St., 7-10 p.m. Friday. A night of art, music, costumes and Tarot readings by candlelight. More than 20 artists with a Tarot card inspired theme. www.revelrygallery.com. 
12th Annual “Bardstown Bound” BooFest. William Dean parking lot; and Douglass Loop, Bardstown Road and Baxter Ave., 2 p.m. Saturday. Boo Alley (William Dean parking lot), haunted boutiques, bars, trick or treating, shopping, drinking, eating and entertainment. ValuMarket will host a candy maze and costume contest for kids and pets. www.bardstownbound.com. 
Southern Indiana Fiber Arts Festival. Masonic Lodge, 805 E. Market St., New Albany, 1-7 p.m. Friday; 9 a.m.-4 p.m. Saturday. Features spinners, weavers and knitters. Music provided by New Albany Production House and view the outdoor exhibits featuring live alpacas. Concerts 
Mac Miller. Mercury Ballroom, 611 S. Fourth St., 8 p.m. Saturday. $35. mercuryballroom.com. 
Rob Thomas, Vinyl Station. Louisville Palace, 625 S. Fourth St., 7:30 p.m. Tuesday. $39.50-$89.50. (800) 745-3000. 
Mat Kearney: Just Kids Tour. Mercury Ballroom, 611 S. Fourth St., 8 p.m. Tuesday. $25. mercuryballroom.com. 
Andy Mineo. Mercury Ballroom, 611 S. Fourth St., 8 p.m. Friday. The Uncomfortable Tour. $22. mercuryballroom.com. 
Third Eye Blind. Brown Theatre, 315 W. Broadway, 8 p.m. Saturday. $27 and $32.50. (502) 584-7777. Don't miss these 5 shows in Louisville Bars & Clubs 
Fourth Street Live! 400 S. Fourth St., 2-8 p.m., Big & Swig: Beer, Bourbon & BBQ Festival. More than 40 craft beers and and bourbons, food trucks and a live pig roast. Music by Whiskey Bent Valley Boys, Old School and Radiotronic. General admission, $40 advance, $50 day of festival; VIP, $70 (advance purchase only) includes BBQ sandwiches (2), 20 sampling tokens, souvenir glass, Gordon Biersch Growler (filled with your choice of select Gordon Biersch beer), souvenir shirt and access to the VIP bridge with exclusive samplings and complimentary snacks. www.4thstlive.com/events 
Headliner’s Music Hall. 1836 Lexington Road., Thursday, Pimps of Joytime, Hank and Cupcakes, $15. Friday, Randall Bramblett Band, Dog House Kitchen, $15. Tuesday, Moth StorySlam, $8. Oct. 28, Shawn Mullins, Chuck Cannon, $15 (general admission, standing); $25 (reserved seating). 
Zanzabar. 2100 S. Preston St., Friday, Howell Dawdy, Lydia Burrell, Brenda, $10. Saturday, Family Dog, Ted Tyro, Beat Awfuls, $5. Sunday, Cold Fronts, Heyrocco, The Elwins, $8. Oct. 28, The Districts, Sun Club, $12. 
Diamond’s Pub. 630 Baxter Ave., Thursday, Wednesday 13, Byzantine, $15. Sunday, Mushroomhead, $25. 
New Albany Production House. 1736 E. Main St., New Albany. Thursday, Survay Says!, The Decline, Before the Streetlights, Goodbye, Goodnight. Friday, Amongst the Waves, Better Than Salem, The Prodepressants. 35 live music picks around Louisville this week On Stage 
“And Then There Were None.” Derby Dinner Playhouse, 525 Marriott Dr., Clarksville, 7:45 p.m. Thursday-Saturday; 1:30 and 7:45 p.m. Sunday; 1 and 7:45 p.m. Oct. 21. Ten strangers are are trapped on an island together and accusations of murder and cyanide laced cocktails fly as one by one they start to die. Presented by Derby Dinner Playhouse. Through Nov. 8. $37-$46. (812) 288-8281. 
Fifth Third Bank’s “Dracula.” Bingham Theatre, Actors Theatre of Louisville, 316 W. Main St., 7:30 p.m. Thursday, Friday, Tuesday and Oct. 28; 4 and 8 p.m. Saturday; 2 and 7 p.m. Sunday. Actor Theatre show is based on Bram Stoker’s Gothic tale of the immortal Transylvanian count. Through Nov. 1. $45-$67. (502) 584-1205. 
David Sedaris, comedian. Whitney Hall, Kentucky Center, 501 W. Main St., 7:30 p.m. Sunday. $45 and $55. (502) 584-7777. 
Moving Collective: X. Ursuline Arts Center, 3114 Lexington Road., 8 p.m. Saturday. Celebrating a decade of dance. $20, $15 students and seniors. brownpapertickets.com. 
“Polaroid Stories.” Thrust Theatre, 2314 S. Floyd St., 8 p.m. Thursday, Friday and Monday; 3 and 8 p.m. Sunday. An examination of truth and mythology as told through the hard-knock lives of street kids. Characters are based on interviews with prostitutes, drug dealers, runaways and homeless youth. Presented by the University of Louisville Theatre Arts. $15, $12 for faculty, staff, alumni and seniors, $8 students. (502) 852-6814. 14 must-see comedians & more this week Kid friendly 
Cryptic Ink Tattoo 2nd Annual Trunk or Treat Auto Show. 12412 Dixie Hwy., Saturday. Games (noon-8 p.m.), pictures takes with Bumblebee car from the movie Transformers, costume contest (5:30 p.m. kids and adults), trunk or treat (6-7 p.m.); best decorated car contest, food and music. 
St. Paul’s Episcopal Church Trunk or Treat. 4700 Lowe Rd., 5:30-7:30 p.m. Saturday. Carnivals games, food, crafts (5:30-6:30 p.m.) and trunk or treat (6:30-7:30 p.m.). Decorate your trunk or vehicle for the contest with prizes. 
13th Annual Trick or Treat Street. The Playtorium, 10616 W. Manslick Road., 6-8 p.m. Thursday. Trick or treating and free refreshments ; costumes encouraged. For ages 12 and younger. Free. 
The World’s Largest Halloween Party: Merry Not Scary. Louisville Zoo, 1100 Trevilian Way, Friday-Sunday. Enter the zoo 5-8:30 p.m. The party provides not-so-scary fun for families and features costumed characters, storybook scenes throughout the zoo, trick-or-treating (for ages 11 and younger), Mary Go-Round ($2); Warthog Express Train ($4); Kaman’s Handimals (starts at $10); Kaman’s Face Painting (starts at $8); Kaman’s Photo Packages (starts at $15) and Louisville Youth Board Face Painting and Sand Art ($1-$4). Presented by Meijer’s. Admission, $9 advance ticket (online); $10 day of event; all area Meijer store will be selling tickets for $8. Parking $5 (cash). (502) 459-2181. www.louisvillezoo.org . 
Science in Play. Kentucky Science Center, 727 W. Main St., 9:30 a.m.-5 p.m. Sunday-Thursday; 9:30 a.m.-9 p.m. Friday and Saturday. A progressive, next-generation learning experience for children and their families. Included with paid admission to the Kentucky Science Center. (502) 560-7128.
